Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Distribution of Patients to Medical Facilities in Mass-Casualty Events

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mass-casualty events such as terrorist attacks and natural disasters can affect hundreds to thousands of people and place significant burdens on emergency response systems for unpredicted periods of time. During these events, the emergency response management faces several complex operational decisions under time pressure and sometimes security and safety concerns. One fundamental decision is how to distribute casualties from the affected areas to multiple medical facilities that differ in capacity, specialty, and distance. Currently, this decision is left to the emergency transport officer in civilian settings and to battlefield commanders during military operations. Using mathematical modeling and analysis in conjunction with medical expertise, this project will build knowledge and decision tools to make casualty distribution more efficiently and objective. This multi-disciplinary project bringing together operations researchers and emergency physicians, will benefit society directly by facilitating effective casualty distribution during disasters. It will also significantly contribute to the education of a diverse group of students from the operations research, public health, and medical fields.


In its most general form, casualty-distribution problem is a stochastic sequential decision making problem that includes various parameters and variables such as the number of casualties at each location; the number of emergency vehicles; the capacity, capability, and congestion levels of each hospital; the travel time between locations and hospitals; and the condition of travel routes. The first phase of the project involves identifying the most fundamental tradeoffs underlying this complex decision-making problem and formulating separate models for each. These models will then be analyzed by means of exact methods such as sample-path analysis and Markov decision processes to obtain insights about the characteristics of optimal decision rules. In the second phase of the project, approximate approaches such as fluid models and Lagrangian relaxations will be used to develop heuristic policies. In the final phase, an extensive simulation study will be conducted to test the principles and decision rules in more realistic settings using data from literature and the 2010 National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey. The mathematical models developed for this project can equivalently be seen as queueing models with dynamic routing. Hence, this project also contributes to the operations research literature by introducing and studying a new class of queue-routing problems, where the travel to queues takes time and possibly requires a scarce resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most important decisions for the success of the overall response effort in the aftermath of a mass-casualty event is how to distribute casualties from affected areas to medical facilities, which differ in their capacity, specialty, and distance. In this project, we used mathematical modeling and analysis to help develop our understanding of this sequential decision problem. In particular, we built a mathematical framework that can be used to develop dynamic decision rules that prescribe which non-ambulatory patients should be transported to which treatment facilities and in what order.

We first formulated the problem as a stochastic sequential decision-making problem and then analyzed this problem first to identify certain characteristics of the optimal decisions (by means of Markov decision process formulations, sample-path comparisons, etc.) and then to develop simple, near-optimal policies based on these characterizations as well as approximate formulations (such as fluid models). We finally conducted an extensive simulation study to test our heuristic policies under realistic conditions. In particular, we compared our heuristics with some benchmarks under realistic scenarios that we categorized into four based on the characteristics of most commonly observed mass-casualty events: (a) single-location terrorist attacks, (b) multiple-location terrorist attacks, (c) major traffic accidents, and (d) earthquakes.  We found that all dynamic heuristics performed significantly better than the naïve nearest-hospital policy under all scenarios except that for the earthquake scenarios, the nearest-hospital policy performed reasonably well. In all scenarios, we observed that the advantage of dynamic policies over the nearest-hospital policy diminishes as the number of medical resources (ambulances or hospital beds) increases.

In the second part of the project, we concentrated on developing decision support tools for improving patient flow in emergency departments and hospitals under both regular operating conditions and emergency conditions. Our initial focus was on developing methods for reducing patient boarding times. The fundamental idea was to identify patients who have a high likelihood of being admitted to the hospital and start the hospital bed identification and patient transfer process for these patients early, at the time of triage. After developing a logistic regression model for estimating the admission probabilities for the patients based on information available at the time of their triage, we developed decision models for determining whether a given probability of admission would be deemed to be high enough for requesting a bed early, possibly based on the conditions of the ED at the time the decision is made. The decision models, which were based on queueing theory and Markov decision processes, led to two policies, one static, which ignores changing conditions in the ED, the other dynamic, which determines whether a given an admission probability is sufficiently high depending on how crowded the ED is. Based on data obtained from an academic hospital in the US, we developed a simulation model for an ED and using this model we compared the performances of the policies we developed. Our findings indicated that our policies have the potential to significantly reduce patients’ ED length-of-stay under acceptable levels of incorrect early bed requests particularly during periods when the ED experiences substantially high levels of patient demand as that would be the case for instance during epidemics.

In the last part of the project, with the ultimate goal of developing a ED crowding prediction tool, which ED and hospital managers can rely on when taking actions to alleviate impending problems, we developed a novel model that can be used to forecast ED census up to a few hours in the future. The model, which combines the standard seasonal time series model SARIMA with some external regressors that are unique to the ED setting, was shown to perform significantly better than the standard time series models, the rolling average model, which is the typical method of choice in practice, and two other models from the literature, which were developed specifically for the same purpose.
